tdee-calculator.title: TDEE Calculator - Free Daily Calorie Burn Tool
tdee-calculator.description: Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE). Free online calorie calculator to plan your diet and fitness goals.

howItWorks.title: How the TDEE Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: TDEE = BMR × Activity Multiplier (1.2 for sedentary to 1.9 for very active)
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates the total calories your body burns daily by multiplying your Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) by your physical activity factor. This number is the foundation for any diet plan, whether for weight loss or gain.

steps.name: Calculate BMR
steps.text: The tool calculates your basal metabolic rate from your weight, height, and age

steps.name: Determine Activity
steps.text: Select your daily and weekly physical activity level

steps.name: Calculate TDEE
steps.text: BMR is multiplied by the activity factor to get total daily burn

useCases.title: Weight Loss Diet Planning
useCases.description: Determine the calorie deficit needed for weight loss

useCases.title: Muscle Building Programs
useCases.description: Know the calorie surplus needed for muscle building

useCases.title: Weight Maintenance
useCases.description: Know the calories needed to maintain your current weight

seoTips: Recalculate TDEE every 4-6 weeks as your weight changes
Be honest when assessing your activity level
Most people overestimate their physical activity
Start with a lower activity level and adjust based on results
commonMistakes: Overestimating physical activity level
Not updating calculations after weight loss or gain
Ignoring non-exercise daily activity (walking, housework)
Relying on one number without adjusting based on actual results

faqs.question: What's the difference between BMR and TDEE?
faqs.answer: BMR is calories burned at complete rest, while TDEE includes all daily activities.

faqs.question: How much should I reduce from TDEE to lose weight?
faqs.answer: A 500 calorie daily deficit leads to about 0.5 kg loss per week.

faqs.question: Is TDEE constant?
faqs.answer: No, it changes with weight, age, activity level, and muscle mass.

bmr-calculator.title: BMR Calculator - Free Basal Metabolic Rate Tool
bmr-calculator.description: Calculate your Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) accurately. Find out how many calories you burn at rest with our free tool.

howItWorks.title: How the BMR Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Mifflin-St Jeor: Men = (10 × weight) + (6.25 × height) - (5 × age) + 5
howItWorks.explanation: Basal Metabolic Rate is the minimum calories your body needs to survive at complete rest. This includes breathing, heart rate, brain function, and vital organ functions.

steps.name: Enter Data
steps.text: Input your weight, height, age, and gender

steps.name: Apply Formulas
steps.text: The calculator uses Mifflin-St Jeor and Harris-Benedict formulas

steps.name: View Results
steps.text: Get your basal metabolic rate in calories

useCases.title: Nutrition Plan Foundation
useCases.description: Know the minimum calories you should never go below

useCases.title: TDEE Calculation
useCases.description: BMR is the basis for calculating total daily burn

useCases.title: Understanding Personal Metabolism
useCases.description: Learn how efficiently your body burns calories

seoTips: Weigh yourself in the morning before eating for accuracy
Muscle mass raises BMR, so exercise is beneficial
Never eat below your BMR for extended periods
BMR decreases with age, so recalculate annually
commonMistakes: Confusing BMR with TDEE and eating only at BMR level
Ignoring the decrease in BMR with weight loss
Not considering the effect of muscle mass on metabolism
Using inaccurate weight and height measurements

faqs.question: Can I increase my BMR?
faqs.answer: Yes, by building muscle mass since muscles burn more calories than fat even at rest.

faqs.question: Why does BMR decrease with age?
faqs.answer: Due to muscle mass loss and slowing of biological processes with aging.

faqs.question: Does BMR differ between men and women?
faqs.answer: Yes, men typically have higher BMR due to greater muscle mass.

calorie-deficit-calculator.title: Calorie Deficit Calculator - Weight Loss Planner
calorie-deficit-calculator.description: Calculate the calorie deficit needed to reach your weight loss goals safely and effectively. Free online weight loss tracker.

howItWorks.title: How the Calorie Deficit Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates the daily calorie deficit needed to reach your target weight in your specified timeframe. Each kilogram of fat contains approximately 7700 calories.

steps.name: Set Goal
steps.text: Enter your current weight and target weight

steps.name: Set Timeline
steps.text: Specify the number of weeks to reach your goal

steps.name: Calculate Deficit
steps.text: The tool calculates the required daily deficit and target calories

useCases.title: Weight Loss Planning
useCases.description: Know how much to reduce calories to reach your goal

useCases.title: Setting Realistic Timelines
useCases.description: Determine a healthy timeframe for weight loss

useCases.title: Diet Adjustments
useCases.description: Calculate daily allowed calories

seoTips: Do not exceed a 1000 calorie daily deficit without medical supervision
A moderate deficit (500 calories) is more sustainable
Combine eating less with moving more
Monitor your energy and mood as indicators of excessive deficit
commonMistakes: Setting unrealistic goals that require dangerous deficits
Ignoring minimum healthy calorie intake (1200 for women, 1500 for men)
Not accounting for calories burned from exercise
Maintaining the same deficit despite weight changes

faqs.question: What is a safe calorie deficit?
faqs.answer: 500-750 calories daily is considered safe and leads to 0.5-0.75 kg loss per week.

faqs.question: Can the deficit be too large?
faqs.answer: Yes, large deficits lead to muscle loss, slowed metabolism, and health problems.

faqs.question: How do I know if my deficit is appropriate?
faqs.answer: If you're losing 0.5-1 kg weekly with good energy, your deficit is appropriate.

macro-calculator.title: Macro Calculator - Protein, Carbs, and Fat Distribution
macro-calculator.description: Calculate your ideal macronutrient (macros) split. Free online macro calculator for bodybuilding, keto, and balanced diets.

howItWorks.title: How the Macro Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Protein: 1.6-2.2 g/kg, Fat: 20-35% of calories, Carbs: remainder
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates macronutrient distribution (protein, carbohydrates, and fat) based on your daily calories and fitness goal. Proper distribution ensures you get the energy and nutrients needed for your goals.

seoTips: Protein is most important for preserving muscle in any goal
Don't reduce fat below 20% to maintain hormones
Adjust carbs based on your activity level
Use a food tracking app to monitor macros
commonMistakes: Focusing only on calories and ignoring macro distribution
Excessively reducing fat which affects hormones
Not eating enough protein when cutting
Ignoring the quality of macro sources

faqs.question: What's the best macro split?
faqs.answer: Depends on your goal: for bulking, approximately 30% protein, 50% carbs, 20% fat.

faqs.question: Are carbs necessary?
faqs.answer: Yes for optimal athletic performance, but can be reduced in certain diets.

faqs.question: How much protein do I need daily?
faqs.answer: 1.6-2.2 grams per kilogram of body weight for athletes.

protein-intake-calculator.title: Protein Intake Calculator - Daily Protein Needs Tool
protein-intake-calculator.description: Calculate how much protein you need per day for muscle growth or maintenance. Free daily protein requirements tool.

howItWorks.title: How the Protein Intake Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Daily Protein = Body Weight (kg) × Goal Factor (1.2-2.4 g/kg)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines your ideal daily protein intake based on your body weight, fitness goal, and activity level. Protein is essential for muscle building, repair, and maintenance, especially during weight loss.

steps.text: Input your current body weight in kilograms

steps.name: Select Goal
steps.text: Choose your goal (muscle building, cutting, maintenance, or sedentary)

steps.name: Select Activity Level
steps.text: Choose your weekly training intensity

useCases.title: Cutting/Fat Loss
useCases.description: Preserve muscle mass during calorie deficits

useCases.title: Injury Recovery
useCases.description: Support muscle tissue repair after injuries

seoTips: Distribute protein across 4-5 meals daily for better absorption
Consume 20-40g protein within 2 hours post-workout for optimal recovery
High-quality protein sources: chicken, fish, eggs, whey, dairy
Drink adequate water with high protein intake to support kidneys
commonMistakes: Consuming all protein in one or two meals, reducing absorption
Relying only on supplements instead of real food
Neglecting protein on rest days despite its importance for recovery
Not adjusting amount after weight or goal changes

faqs.question: How much protein do I need daily?
faqs.answer: 1.6-2.2 g/kg for athletes, 1.2-1.6 for moderate activity, 0.8-1.0 for sedentary individuals.

faqs.question: Can excess protein harm kidneys?
faqs.answer: No for healthy individuals. Those with kidney issues should consult a doctor.

faqs.question: Does protein timing matter?
faqs.answer: Distribution throughout the day matters more than exact timing, but post-workout protein aids recovery.

weight-gain-calculator.title: Weight Gain Calculator - Bulking Diet Plan
weight-gain-calculator.description: Calculate daily calories and macros for healthy weight gain. Free online tool for muscle building and bulking diets.
weight-gain-calculator.tdee_tooltip: Enter your Total Daily Energy Expenditure
weight-gain-calculator.tips_list: Eat in a slight calorie surplus (300-500 cal above TDEE), focus on compound exercises, get adequate sleep for recovery, track progress weekly
weight-gain-calculator.empty_state: Enter your details to calculate bulking plan
weight-gain-calculator.footer_note: Weight gain should be gradual. Aim for 0.25-0.5kg per week for muscle gain.

howItWorks.title: How the Weight Gain Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Daily Calories = TDEE + (Weekly Gain Target × 7700 calories ÷ 7 days)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines the daily calorie surplus and macronutrient breakdown needed to gain weight at your desired rate. Gaining 1 kg requires approximately 7700 excess calories, so the calculator adds the appropriate surplus to your maintenance calories.

useCases.description: Calculate calorie needs for athletes needing to move up a weight class

seoTips: A 300-500 calorie surplus is optimal for lean muscle gain with minimal fat
Aim for 0.25-0.5 kg weekly gain to maximize muscle and minimize fat accumulation
Protein intake should be 1.6-2.2 g/kg body weight when bulking
Combine calorie surplus with progressive resistance training for best results
commonMistakes: Eating too large a surplus leading to excessive fat gain
Not training hard enough to stimulate muscle growth
Relying on junk food instead of nutrient-dense calorie sources
Gaining weight too quickly and accumulating unnecessary body fat

faqs.question: How much weight should I gain per week?
faqs.answer: 0.25-0.5 kg weekly for lean gains. Faster rates typically mean more fat than muscle.

faqs.question: How many extra calories do I need?
faqs.answer: 300-500 calories above TDEE is sufficient for most people to build muscle.

faqs.question: What if I am gaining fat?
faqs.answer: Reduce your surplus slightly and ensure you are training hard enough to stimulate muscle growth.

weight-loss-time-calculator.title: Weight Loss Time Calculator - Goal Timeline
weight-loss-time-calculator.description: Calculate how long it will take to reach your weight loss goal. Free online tool for healthy weight loss planning.

howItWorks.title: How the Weight Loss Time Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Weeks Required = (Current Weight - Target Weight) ÷ Weekly Loss Rate
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines how long it will take to reach your target weight based on your chosen weekly weight loss rate. This helps you set realistic expectations and plan better.

steps.name: Enter Current Weight
steps.text: Input your current body weight in kilograms

steps.name: Enter Target Weight
steps.text: Input the weight you want to achieve

steps.name: Set Loss Rate

useCases.title: Event Planning
useCases.description: Plan for a specific event like a wedding or trip

useCases.title: Reality Check
useCases.description: Determine if your goal is achievable in the given timeframe

seoTips: 0.5-1 kg weekly loss is the healthiest and most sustainable rate
Slower weight loss preserves muscle better
Plan for plateaus that naturally slow progress
Closer goals are easier to stay motivated for than distant ones
commonMistakes: Expecting unsustainably rapid loss (more than 1 kg weekly) long-term
Not accounting for plateaus that extend the actual timeline
Setting rigid deadlines that cause psychological stress
Comparing your loss rate with others

faqs.question: What is a healthy weight loss rate?
faqs.answer: 0.5-1 kg weekly for most people. Extreme obesity may allow higher rates initially.

faqs.question: Why does weight loss stop sometimes?
faqs.answer: Due to body adaptation. Requires adjusting calories, increasing activity, or taking a short maintenance break.

faqs.question: Can I speed up weight loss?
faqs.answer: Yes through increased activity, but increasing calorie deficit beyond 1000 is unhealthy.

weight-loss-time-calculator.weekly_loss_tooltip: Enter desired weekly weight loss (0.1-2 kg)
weight-loss-time-calculator.tips_list: Aim for 0.5-1 kg per week for sustainable weight loss, combine diet and exercise for best results, stay hydrated and get adequate sleep, consult a healthcare professional before starting any weight loss program
weight-loss-time-calculator.empty_state: Enter your weight details to calculate timeline
weight-loss-time-calculator.footer_note: Results are estimates. Individual results may vary based on metabolism and lifestyle.

bmr.title: Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) Calculator
bmr.description: Calculate the number of calories your body burns at rest to maintain its vital functions.
bmr.about_desc: Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) is the minimum amount of energy your body needs to survive at complete rest.
bmr.empty_state: Enter your data to calculate your Basal Metabolic Rate
bmr.footer_note: Results vary slightly depending on the formula used.

howItWorks.title: How the BMR Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Mifflin-St Jeor: Men = (10 × weight) + (6.25 × height) - (5 × age) + 5
howItWorks.explanation: Basal Metabolic Rate represents the minimum calories your body needs to maintain vital functions at complete rest, including breathing, circulation, brain function, and organ maintenance. This calculator uses multiple validated formulas to provide accurate estimates.

steps.text: Input your weight, height, age, and gender

seoTips: Weigh yourself in the morning before eating for the most accurate input
Building muscle mass increases BMR since muscle burns more calories than fat
Never consistently eat below your BMR as it can slow metabolism
Recalculate BMR annually as it naturally decreases with age
commonMistakes: Confusing BMR with TDEE and eating only at BMR level
Not accounting for BMR decrease after significant weight loss
Ignoring the impact of muscle mass on metabolic rate
Using inaccurate weight or height measurements

faqs.question: Can I increase my BMR?
faqs.answer: Yes, primarily by building muscle mass. Muscle tissue burns more calories than fat, even at rest.

faqs.question: Why does BMR decrease with age?
faqs.answer: Due to natural muscle mass loss (sarcopenia) and slower biological processes that occur with aging.

faqs.question: Is BMR different for men and women?
faqs.answer: Yes, men typically have higher BMR due to greater muscle mass and different hormonal profiles.

tdee.title: Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) Calculator
tdee.description: Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) based on your activity level.
tdee.about_desc: Total Daily Energy Expenditure is an estimate of how many calories you burn per day considering your physical activity.
tdee.empty_state: Enter your data to calculate your total daily calories
tdee.footer_note: For best results, recalculate whenever your weight or activity level changes.

howItWorks.title: How the TDEE Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: TDEE = BMR × Activity Multiplier (1.2 for sedentary to 1.9 for very active)
howItWorks.explanation: Total Daily Energy Expenditure calculates the total calories your body burns daily by multiplying your Basal Metabolic Rate by an activity factor. This number is the foundation for any diet plan, whether for weight loss, maintenance, or muscle building.

steps.name: Calculate BMR
steps.text: The tool calculates your basal metabolic rate from weight, height, and age

steps.text: Select your daily and weekly physical activity level

steps.name: Calculate TDEE
steps.text: BMR is multiplied by the activity factor to get total daily calorie burn

seoTips: Recalculate TDEE every 4-6 weeks as your weight changes
Be honest when assessing your activity level for accurate results
Most people overestimate their physical activity level
Start with a lower activity level and adjust based on actual weight changes
commonMistakes: Overestimating physical activity level leading to incorrect calorie targets
Not updating calculations after significant weight loss or gain
Ignoring non-exercise activity thermogenesis (NEAT) like walking and housework
Relying on one calculation without adjusting based on real-world results

faqs.question: What is the difference between BMR and TDEE?
faqs.answer: BMR is calories burned at complete rest, while TDEE includes all daily activities and exercise.

faqs.question: How much should I reduce from TDEE to lose weight?
faqs.answer: A 500-calorie daily deficit leads to approximately 0.5 kg (1 lb) weight loss per week.

faqs.question: Is TDEE constant?
faqs.answer: No, it changes with weight, age, activity level, muscle mass, and hormonal factors.

seoTips: Protein is the most important macro for preserving muscle during any weight change
Never reduce fat below 20% of calories to maintain hormone health
Adjust carbohydrate intake based on activity level and training intensity
Use a food tracking app to monitor actual macro intake vs targets
commonMistakes: Focusing only on calories while ignoring macronutrient distribution
Reducing fat too aggressively which can affect hormone levels
Not eating enough protein when cutting, leading to muscle loss
Ignoring the quality of macro sources (whole foods vs processed)

faqs.question: What is the best macro split?
faqs.answer: It depends on your goal. For bulking: approximately 30% protein, 45% carbs, 25% fat. For cutting: 35% protein, 35% carbs, 30% fat.

faqs.question: Are carbohydrates necessary?
faqs.answer: Yes for optimal athletic performance and recovery. They can be reduced in certain diets like keto, but most athletes benefit from adequate carbs.

faqs.question: How much protein do I need daily?
faqs.answer: For active individuals: 1.6-2.2 g per kg of body weight. Higher end for cutting, lower end for maintenance.

calorie_deficit.title: Calorie Deficit Calculator
calorie_deficit.description: Calculate the calorie deficit needed to reach your weight loss goals safely and effectively.
calorie_deficit.warning_deficit_desc: A daily deficit over 1000 calories is generally not recommended without medical supervision.
calorie_deficit.warning_calories_desc: Eating less than 1200 calories per day may not provide sufficient nutrients.
calorie_deficit.tip_track: Track your food intake to ensure accuracy
calorie_deficit.empty_state: Enter your weight goals to calculate the required deficit
calorie_deficit.footer_note: 1 kg of fat is approximately 7700 calories.

howItWorks.title: How the Calorie Deficit Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Daily Deficit = (Weight to Lose in kg × 7700 calories) / (Weeks × 7 days)
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates the daily calorie deficit required to reach your target weight in your specified timeframe. Since 1 kg of body fat contains approximately 7700 calories, the calculator determines how much you need to reduce daily intake below your TDEE.

seoTips: A deficit of 500-750 calories per day is sustainable for most people
Do not exceed 1000 calorie deficit without medical supervision
Combine reduced eating with increased activity for best results
Monitor energy levels and mood as indicators of excessive restriction
commonMistakes: Setting unrealistic goals requiring dangerously large deficits
Going below minimum healthy intake (1200 cal for women, 1500 for men)
Not accounting for exercise calories burned
Maintaining the same deficit as weight decreases without recalculating

faqs.question: What is a safe calorie deficit?
faqs.answer: 500-750 calories daily is considered safe and sustainable, leading to 0.5-0.75 kg loss per week.

faqs.question: Can the deficit be too large?
faqs.answer: Yes. Deficits over 1000 calories can cause muscle loss, metabolic slowdown, and nutritional deficiencies.

faqs.question: How do I know if my deficit is appropriate?
faqs.answer: If you are losing 0.5-1 kg per week with good energy and no excessive hunger, your deficit is likely appropriate.

howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines your daily protein requirements based on your body weight, fitness goal, and activity level. Protein is essential for muscle repair, growth, and maintenance. Requirements increase with activity level and especially during muscle-building or fat-loss phases.

seoTips: Distribute protein intake across 4-5 meals for optimal absorption
Consume 20-40g protein within 2 hours after workouts for recovery
High-quality complete proteins (meat, fish, eggs, dairy) are most effective
Increase water intake when consuming high protein to support kidney function
commonMistakes: Consuming all protein in one or two meals instead of spreading throughout the day

Not adjusting protein intake when goals or activity levels change
Ignoring protein quality and focusing only on total grams

faqs.question: How much protein do I need to build muscle?
faqs.answer: For muscle building: 1.6-2.2 g per kg of body weight daily, combined with resistance training.

faqs.question: Can I eat too much protein?
faqs.answer: Excess protein beyond needs is used for energy or stored. Very high intakes may stress kidneys in those with kidney issues.

faqs.question: When is the best time to eat protein?
faqs.answer: Spread evenly across meals. Post-workout protein (within 2 hours) is beneficial but total daily intake matters most.

howItWorks.formula: Weeks to Goal = (Current Weight - Target Weight) / Weekly Loss Rate
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates how long it will take to reach your target weight based on your chosen weekly loss rate. Understanding the timeline helps set realistic expectations and plan your weight loss journey effectively.

useCases.title: Expectation Setting

seoTips: Aim for 0.5-1 kg per week for sustainable, healthy weight loss
Faster loss rates often lead to muscle loss and metabolic adaptation
Combine calorie reduction with exercise for best results
Plan for occasional plateaus which are normal during weight loss
commonMistakes: Setting unrealistic weekly loss targets that are unsustainable
Not accounting for weight loss plateaus that naturally occur
Expecting linear progress when weight loss naturally fluctuates
Starting too aggressively and burning out before reaching the goal

faqs.question: What is a safe rate of weight loss?
faqs.answer: 0.5-1 kg per week is considered safe and sustainable for most people. Faster rates may lead to muscle loss.

faqs.question: Why does weight loss slow down over time?
faqs.answer: As you lose weight, your body requires fewer calories, and metabolic adaptation occurs. Recalculate your needs periodically.

faqs.question: Can I lose weight faster?
faqs.answer: While possible, faster loss often means losing muscle along with fat and is harder to maintain long-term.

water-intake-calculator.title: Water Intake Calculator - Daily Hydration Needs
water-intake-calculator.description: Calculate how much water you should drink daily based on your weight and activity level. Free online hydration calculator.

howItWorks.title: How the Water Intake Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Basic Intake = Weight (kg) × 30-35 ml, plus 500-1000 ml for physical activity
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates the water your body needs daily based on your weight, physical activity level, and climate. Adequate hydration is essential for physical and mental performance and overall health.

steps.name: Enter Weight
steps.text: Input your body weight in kilograms

steps.name: Set Activity
steps.text: Select your daily physical activity level

steps.name: Calculate Needs
steps.text: The tool calculates recommended daily water intake

useCases.title: Athletes
useCases.description: Replace fluids lost during exercise and competition

useCases.title: Weight Loss
useCases.description: Drinking water helps reduce appetite and improve metabolism

useCases.title: General Health
useCases.description: Maintain proper body function

seoTips: Distribute water intake throughout the day - don't drink it all at once
Drink a glass of water before each meal
Increase intake on hot days or when exercising
Monitor urine color - light yellow indicates good hydration
commonMistakes: Waiting until thirsty to drink (thirst means dehydration has started)
Relying on soda or coffee instead of water
Drinking large amounts at once
Ignoring increased needs in hot weather

faqs.question: How many liters of water do I need daily?
faqs.answer: Average is 2-3 liters for adults, but varies by weight, activity, and climate.

faqs.question: Can I drink too much water?
faqs.answer: Yes, rare overhydration can cause sodium deficiency, but it's very uncommon.

faqs.question: Do tea and coffee count?
faqs.answer: Partially, but pure water is best since caffeine is a diuretic.

errors.age_range: Age must be between 15 and 100 years
errors.weight_positive: Weight must be a positive and realistic value
errors.height_positive: Height must be a positive and realistic value
